Normally, they are gone in a separate package the mirror the class being
test. Example, 
Class Book is located in edu.washington.library so the test class is
BookTest and is located in test.edu.washington.library. This allows for
elimating the classes for production.

As for testing private/package/etc. The intent is to test the public
interface to make sure it is correct. There are tools that allow for
testing in the class like using inner classes. These can be striped as
well in product role. Again, normally they are placed in the example
above but as usual it would depend on the development team and what
their goals are for the project.

To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Where to place test classes?


I am looking for some opinions on where to place test
classes in my project.  Here ware what I feel are some
of my options.

1.  Place the test classes inside of the classes they
are testing.  This method allows me to test private
methods.  This option alters the content of the class
itself.

2.  Place the test classes in the same package as the
classes they are testing.  This option will not allow
me to test private methods, but will allow me to test
protected methods.  This option alters the original
package contents, but not the original classes.

3.  Place the test classes in a special test package. 
This option does not allow me to test private or
protected methods.  This option does not alter the
original class or package.

Please let me know what you think.  Thanks!
